health engagement management and acts on behalf of healthcare organizations such as hospitals clinics pharmacies and
insurance companies to help people close clinical gaps our mission is to engage people at the right time with the right
message and over the right channels in order to improve population health and provide objective data to our customers
relative to their efficiency and Effectiveness Eliza helps its customers engage in the pay for performance model
in this model the payers and providers are incentivized to keep focused on the care and well-being of the populations
and it's the outcomes that matter most versus the number and types of services people receive this is definitely a big
job and requires us to process and analyze a good deal of data for example we process the healthc care data for
over 55 million Americans every year this translates to millions of interactions per day and hundreds of
millions of interactions per year a handful of our key stores house approximately a trillion records so this
creates some challenges as you might imagine that we'll talk about so Eliza analyzes more than 300
million outreaches per year primarily through outbound phone calls with interactive voice response or ivr
technology but other channels such as SMS email and inbound ivr are growing uh quite rapidly for Eliza interactions
take the form of healthcare questions and answers the questions are implemented as a decision tree and we
capture each unique question answer pair as a tuple an example would be something like did you visit your physician the
last 30 days yes or no this means that a lier captures and needs to process Millions upon millions of name value
pairs continually keeping the data in its raw form is important as it makes analysis
and Reporting as flexible as possible imposing a schema on right can limit our ability to do ad hoc and whatif analyses
additionally our internal clients such as data science and Analytics need different slices and Views as they use
the data in very different ways serving multiple diverse groups can be quite challenging if data conforms to a single
rigid schema it's interesting to note that we used to store all of these pairs in red shift and had to Pivot them for
Downstream consumption over time this pivoting became extremely timec consuming leading us to rethink our data
strategy our strategic goals in developing a Next Generation data platform were to create one with to
create an architecture to support continued growth in new functionality allowing for maximum flexibility in
analysis and Reporting uh also to have the ability to ingest transform and process old as well
as new data streams we also wanted to allow for both real time and batch processing with little human
intervention in addition we set out to provide metadata a catalog and Discovery
capabilities for content in the data store to enable and control access to data through entitlements and governance
and to increase the level of self-service for our end
users uh these needs led us to consider a data Lake architecture the conceptual architecture shown here has three main
layers so moving from left to right in the diagram uh we first have an injest layer that accepts a variety of data
formats along both batch and streaming Pathways moving to the right we have a
conditioning layer where data quality and governance rules can be applied keeping corrupted or inaccurate data out
of the lake at this layer we can also generate and add metadata to any and all
data streams the metadata supports search Discovery and intelligent life cycle management scenarios on the right
we see a consumption layer where Downstream clients can access and subsequently analyze the data in
addition to these primary layers this canonical architecture readily supports data access control and centralized
auditing so some benefit of uh this platform talk about one set of benefits and talk a little bit about the
architecture then talk about the architectural benefits um The Hub and spoke model provide a single copy and
single source of Truth for all Enterprise analytics data this prevents us from having to make multiple copies
of the same data and limits data transitions we're able to take manual processes out of workflows and
streamline and automate ingestion of the source data we can apply consistent quality checks Transformations and
conditioning keeping the operation data reliable and clean we can apply consistent centralized access through
entitlements and role-based Security Management and we can service multiple Downstream customers through projecting
the data as needed and we'll show this uh the projection layer on the next slide this architecture also enables us
to free our data warehouse implemented in redshift from having to be what was a jack of all trades we can now Focus
redshift on what it's great at data
warehousing so this is a high level diagram of our data L platform and again working from left to right in the
diagram in our implementation Outreach results for example call dispositions uh
SMS responses those types of things flow into the system through AWS Kinesis streams on a continuous real-time basis
and we perform near realtime analysis using Kinesis analytics and this enables us to radiate Outreach activity and
volume statistics to our Network Operation Center other data such as custom member profile FES come in
through secure FTP and land in a uh raw data bucket as a design principle data
always flows from left to right through the platform this helps to prevent dirty data from ever polluting the
lake okay the system takes the raw data and passes it through a conditioning layer here we apply data quality rules
generate metadata for Downstream data access and client consumption and build a metadata index for Rapid search and
retrieval we also build a search index providing various mechanisms for clients
to retrieve exactly what they need very rapidly we move the data through the system at scale using spark jobs on EMR
clusters and store some of the byproducts in Dynamo DB after passing through the conditioning layer we store
the data in S3 buckets that use randomized keys to achieve an operationally effective distribution of
the data across partitions moving to the storage layer where the data is now quote cooked we
use Dynamo DB to store the catalog and metadata which provides a rapidly accessible map of the data space which
clients can use to find and read data as needed and IAM policies control all access on the data access and
consumption side on the right of the diagram the lake serves a variety of clients using projections and you can
think of these projections as views into the data that are materialized either real time or updated on a periodic basis
in batch two examples include we make ad hoc querying available to our analytics and data science teams using Hive and
Presto and we feed the Enterprise data warehouse hosted on redshift both of these are different kinds of
projections internal clients can access the data through projections or can access it using a readon
API in terms of the uh the major Services uh we use uh that that diagram
is previous diagram is sort of an architectural soup so I won't go through uh all of these but I'll just uh
highlight a couple things in addition to S3 we process coming streaming data using Kinesis streams and analytics we
store our data catalog and metadata in Dynamo we use Aurora for some internal housekeeping um and at times when we
need uh transactional semantics we we do tend to Now default to Aurora for that
uh Hive and Presto are used to serve our SQL based clients to perform ad hoc queries into interface to analysis to
tools uh such as Tableau and we use cloud search to index our catalog and some select data for Rapid retrieval by
Downstream client systems so additional benefits here um
of the new platform include we have a robust architecture to support inest and data processing at scale we have
improved business agility to allow schema Onre we've architecturally separated compute and storage and allow
each to scale independently this has helped us manage costs quite effectively we've reduced cycle time for end-to-end
client analytics by about 50% a portal where customers can view reports and control Outreach flows now
receives near realtime updates uh in the future we're considering applying machine learning to data sets to
